body:
What onnxruntime version are you using?

Can you also please double check that the project with the error is using the Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.Gpu nuget package and not Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime?

> What onnxruntime version are you using?
> Can you also please double check that the project with the error is using the Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.Gpu nuget package and not Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime?

	<ItemGroup>
		<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.Gpu" Version="1.9.0" />
		<PackageReference Include="System.Drawing.Common" Version="5.0.2" />
	</ItemGroup>

**May be related to this problem** Console test (Windows 10) to create 'InferenceSession' only: - Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk", OutputType = Exe, TargetFramework=net5.0, - PackageReference Include="Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.Gpu" Version="1.9.0" , also resulted in an error: > HResult=0x80131500 Message=[ErrorCode:RuntimeException] D:\a\_work\1\s\include\onnxruntime\core/common/logging/logging.h:313 onnxruntime::logging::LoggingManager::DefaultLogger Attempt to use DefaultLogger but none has been registered. Source=Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime StackTrace: at Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.NativeApiStatus.VerifySuccess(IntPtr nativeStatus) at Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.SessionOptions.MakeSessionOptionWithCudaProvider(Int32 deviceId) at OnnxGpuTestConsole.Program.Main(String[] args)
Project: After build - The composition is similar, and file sizes are equals: But, result of Debug run:

While your app is running in the debugger can you try running this tool to check where it's loading onnxruntime.dll from?

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/listdlls

Provide the exe name as the argument. 

Relevant DLLs I see

>C:\Users\me\source\repos\CSharpOrt\CSharpOrt\bin\Debug\net5.0\Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.dll
C:\Users\me\source\repos\CSharpOrt\CSharpOrt\bin\Debug\net5.0\runtimes\win-x64\native\onnxruntime.DLL
C:\Users\me\source\repos\CSharpOrt\CSharpOrt\bin\Debug\net5.0\runtimes\win-x64\native\onnxruntime_providers_shared.dll
C:\Users\me\source\repos\CSharpOrt\CSharpOrt\bin\Debug\net5.0\runtimes\win-x64\native\onnxruntime_providers_cuda.dll
C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v11.4\bin\cudart64_110.dll
C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v11.4\bin\cublas64_11.dll
C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v11.4\bin\cudnn64_8.dll
C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v11.4\bin\cufft64_10.dll
C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v11.4\bin\cublasLt64_11.dll

Sorry,
I probably didn't express the problem clearly.

It's not that the console app isn't working.
It shouldn't have worked - the "CUDA" is not installed in the execute environment.
The problem is that when an error occurs, the message does not indicate what to do to resolve the error.
For example, in a console application, the error message points to the "...DefaultLogger...", although most likely the installation is missing "CUDA..."

I need to run the application in the Docker container (Linux).
But, according to the exception message:

>System.EntryPointNotFoundException: Unable to find an entry point named 'OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_CUDA' in shared library 'onnxruntime'

it is not clear what is missing.

Maybe a container
`nvidia/cuda: 11.4.2-devel-ubuntu20.04` (from [CUDA and cuDNN images from gitlab.com/nvidia/cuda](https://hub.docker.com/r/nvidia/cuda/tags) )
does not contain the required components?
Or, which base container is suitable for use?

In your most recent setup where the entry point is found, but you're running the code in an environment that does not have CUDA installed, I believe the issue is the environment (which creates the logger) is lazy initialized in InferenceSession but the error is triggered before that happens. If you add the following before creating the session options do you get an error about CUDA not being able to be loaded?
```csharp
var ortEnvInstance = OrtEnv.Instance();
var so = SessionOptions.MakeSessionOptionWithCudaProvider(0);
...
```

With the original issue, if it's unable to find the entry point in the shared library that would typically result from using the Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime package and calling OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_CUDA. However you stated you were using Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.Gpu which should include the entry point. Did you check all the files in the nuget packages in this setup to validate it's the Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.Gpu package or just in the setup on the machine without CUDA?
Checked, in the container image, in the application directory, there are onnxruntime library files, and CUDA components, as follow:

If you run `readelf -Ws /app/runtimes/linux-x64/native/libonnxruntime.so |
grep OrtSessionOptions` does it list the CUDA entry point? 

If so, it most likely isn't loading that shared library at runtime.
If not, that would indicate the shared library didn't come from Microsoft.ML.Onnxruntime.Gpu

This is what I see (running from WSL)
```
readelf -Ws /mnt/c/Users/me/.nuget/packages/microsoft.ml.onnxruntime/1.9.0/runtimes/linux-x64/native/libonnxruntime.so |
grep OrtSessionOptions
   291: 00000000002bd100   388 FUNC    GLOBAL DEFAULT   12 OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_CPU@@VERS_1.9.0

readelf -Ws /mnt/c/Users/me/.nuget/packages/microsoft.ml.onnxruntime.gpu/1.9.0/runtimes/linux-x64/native/libonnxruntime.s
o | grep OrtSessionOptions
   294: 00000000001b7820   108 FUNC    GLOBAL DEFAULT   12 OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_CUDA@@VERS_1.9.0
   296: 00000000002cdff0   388 FUNC    GLOBAL DEFAULT   12 OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_CPU@@VERS_1.9.0
   297: 00000000001b7910   391 FUNC    GLOBAL DEFAULT   12 OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_Tensorrt@@VERS_1.9.0
```
>readelf -Ws /app/runtimes/linux-x64/native/libonnxruntime.so | grep OrtSessionOptions Strange, but there are no other providers in the list besides the CPU

**From local host nuget cache**

_From WSL, for so_:

>readelf -Ws /mnt/c/Users/samso/.nuget/packages/microsoft.ml.onnxruntime.gpu/1.9.0/runtimes/linux-x64/native/libonnxruntime.so | grep OrtSessionOptions

   294: 00000000001b7820   108 FUNC    GLOBAL DEFAULT   12 OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_CUDA@@VERS_1.9.0
   296: 00000000002cdff0   388 FUNC    GLOBAL DEFAULT   12 OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_CPU@@VERS_1.9.0
   297: 00000000001b7910   391 FUNC    GLOBAL DEFAULT   12 OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_Tensorrt@@VERS_1.9.0

_From command console, for dll_:

> dumpbin /EXPORTS C:\Users\samso\.nuget\packages\microsoft.ml.onnxruntime.gpu\1.9.0\runtimes\win-x64\native\onnxruntime.dll

Dump of file C:\Users\samso\.nuget\packages\microsoft.ml.onnxruntime.gpu\1.9.0\runtimes\win-x64\native\onnxruntime.dll

File Type: DLL

  Section contains the following exports for onnxruntime.dll

    00000000 characteristics
    FFFFFFFF time date stamp
        0.00 version
           1 ordinal base
           4 number of functions
           4 number of names

    ordinal hint RVA      name

          1    0 000208C0 OrtGetApiBase
          2    1 000DF4A0 OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_CPU
          3    2 00030C80 OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_CUDA
          4    3 00030860 OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_Tensorrt
When the Docker container is building, the packages are restored from the source

This problem has been resolved.
The reason was that solution there were several projects with different packages: 
Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime - where the GPU was not supposed to be used
and Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.Gpu - where the GPU was supposed to be used.
Most likely, during "dotnet restore", some files overwritten others.
I left only one version of Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.Gpu for all projects, and everything fell into place.
Thank you for answers.
